seg-source.mrk: Aggregates (set functions)

target.mrk: Aggregates (set functions)

trans-unit.source: This section describes aggregates (also described as set functions in ANSI SQL-92 and as column functions in some database literature).

seg-source.mrk: This section describes aggregates (also described as set functions in ANSI SQL-92 and as column functions in some database literature).

target.mrk: This section describes aggregates (also described as set functions in ANSI SQL-92 and as column functions in some database literature).

seg-source.mrk: Aggregates

target.mrk: Aggregates

seg-source.mrk: and data types

target.mrk: and data types

seg-source.mrk: Aggregates

target.mrk: Aggregates

seg-source.mrk: requirements for

target.mrk: requirements for

trans-unit.source: Aggregates provide a means of evaluating an expression over a set of rows. Whereas the other built-in functions operate on a single expression, aggregates operate on a set of values and reduce them to a single scalar value. Built-in aggregates can calculate the minimum, maximum, sum, count, and average of an expression over a set of values as well as count rows.

seg-source.mrk: Aggregates provide a means of evaluating an expression over a set of rows.
Whereas the other built-in functions operate on a single expression, aggregates operate on a set of values and reduce them to a single scalar value.
Built-in aggregates can calculate the minimum, maximum, sum, count, and average of an expression over a set of values as well as count rows.

target.mrk: Aggregates provide a means of evaluating an expression over a set of rows.
Whereas the other built-in functions operate on a single expression, aggregates operate on a set of values and reduce them to a single scalar value.
Built-in aggregates can calculate the minimum, maximum, sum, count, and average of an expression over a set of values as well as count rows.

trans-unit.source: In addition to the built-in aggregates, <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> allows you to create custom aggregate operators, called user-defined aggregates (UDAs). For information on creating and removing UDAs, see <xref href="rrefsqljcreateaggregate.dita#rrefsqljcreateaggregate"></xref> and <xref href="rrefsqljdropaggregate.dita#rrefsqljdropaggregate"></xref>. See <xref href="rrefsqljgrant.dita#rrefsqljgrant"></xref> and <xref href="rrefsqljrevoke.dita#rrefsqljrevoke"></xref> for information on usage privileges for UDAs.

seg-source.mrk: In addition to the built-in aggregates, <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> allows you to create custom aggregate operators, called user-defined aggregates (UDAs).
For information on creating and removing UDAs, see <xref href="rrefsqljcreateaggregate.dita#rrefsqljcreateaggregate"></xref> and <xref href="rrefsqljdropaggregate.dita#rrefsqljdropaggregate"></xref>.
See <xref href="rrefsqljgrant.dita#rrefsqljgrant"></xref> and <xref href="rrefsqljrevoke.dita#rrefsqljrevoke"></xref> for information on usage privileges for UDAs.

target.mrk: In addition to the built-in aggregates, <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> allows you to create custom aggregate operators, called user-defined aggregates (UDAs).
For information on creating and removing UDAs, see <xref href="rrefsqljcreateaggregate.dita#rrefsqljcreateaggregate"></xref> and <xref href="rrefsqljdropaggregate.dita#rrefsqljdropaggregate"></xref>.
See <xref href="rrefsqljgrant.dita#rrefsqljgrant"></xref> and <xref href="rrefsqljrevoke.dita#rrefsqljrevoke"></xref> for information on usage privileges for UDAs.

trans-unit.source: For information on writing the Java classes that implement UDAs, see "Programming user-defined aggregates" in the <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#pub/citdevelop"></ph>.

seg-source.mrk: For information on writing the Java classes that implement UDAs, see "Programming user-defined aggregates" in the <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#pub/citdevelop"></ph>.

target.mrk: For information on writing the Java classes that implement UDAs, see "Programming user-defined aggregates" in the <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#pub/citdevelop"></ph>.

trans-unit.source: Aggregates are permitted only in the following:

seg-source.mrk: Aggregates are permitted only in the following:

target.mrk: Aggregates are permitted only in the following:

seg-source.mrk: A selectItem in a selectExpression.

target.mrk: A selectItem in a selectExpression.

seg-source.mrk: A <xref href="rrefsqlj14854.dita#rrefsqlj14854">HAVING clause</xref>.

target.mrk: A <xref href="rrefsqlj14854.dita#rrefsqlj14854">HAVING clause</xref>.

trans-unit.source: An ORDER BY clause (using an alias name) if the aggregate appears in the result of the relevant query block. That is, an alias for an aggregate is permitted in an ORDER BY clause if and only if the aggregate appears in a selectItem in a selectExpression.

seg-source.mrk: An <xref href="rrefsqlj13658.dita#rrefsqlj13658">ORDER BY clause</xref> (using an alias name) if the aggregate appears in the result of the relevant query block.
That is, an alias for an aggregate is permitted in an ORDER BY clause if and only if the aggregate appears in a selectItem in a selectExpression.

target.mrk: An <xref href="rrefsqlj13658.dita#rrefsqlj13658">ORDER BY clause</xref> (using an alias name) if the aggregate appears in the result of the relevant query block.
That is, an alias for an aggregate is permitted in an ORDER BY clause if and only if the aggregate appears in a selectItem in a selectExpression.

trans-unit.source: All expressions in selectItems in the selectExpression must be either aggregates or grouped columns (see ). (The same is true if there is a HAVING clause without a GROUP BY clause.) This is because the ResultSet of a selectExpression must be either a scalar (single value) or a vector (multiple values), but not a mixture of both. (Aggregates evaluate to a scalar value, and the reference to a column can evaluate to a vector.) For example, the following query mixes scalar and vector values and thus is not valid:

seg-source.mrk: All expressions in selectItems in the selectExpression must be either aggregates or grouped columns (see ).

(The same is true if there is a HAVING clause without a GROUP BY clause.) This is because the ResultSet of a selectExpression must be either a scalar (single value) or a vector (multiple values), but not a mixture of both.
(Aggregates evaluate to a scalar value, and the reference to a column can evaluate to a vector.) For example, the following query mixes scalar and vector values and thus is not valid:

target.mrk: All expressions in selectItems in the selectExpression must be either aggregates or grouped columns (see ).

(The same is true if there is a HAVING clause without a GROUP BY clause.) This is because the ResultSet of a selectExpression must be either a scalar (single value) or a vector (multiple values), but not a mixture of both.
(Aggregates evaluate to a scalar value, and the reference to a column can evaluate to a vector.) For example, the following query mixes scalar and vector values and thus is not valid:

trans-unit.source: -- not valid SELECT MIN(flying_time), flight_id FROM Flights

seg-source.mrk: -- not valid SELECT MIN(flying_time), flight_id FROM Flights

target.mrk: -- not valid SELECT MIN(flying_time), flight_id FROM Flights

trans-unit.source: Aggregates are not allowed on outer references (correlations). This means that if a subquery contains an aggregate, that aggregate cannot evaluate an expression that includes a reference to a column in the outer query block. For example, the following query is not valid because SUM operates on a column from the outer query:

seg-source.mrk: Aggregates are not allowed on outer references (correlations).
This means that if a subquery contains an aggregate, that aggregate cannot evaluate an expression that includes a reference to a column in the outer query block.
For example, the following query is not valid because SUM operates on a column from the outer query:

target.mrk: Aggregates are not allowed on outer references (correlations).
This means that if a subquery contains an aggregate, that aggregate cannot evaluate an expression that includes a reference to a column in the outer query block.
For example, the following query is not valid because SUM operates on a column from the outer query:

trans-unit.source: SELECT c1 FROM t1 GROUP BY c1 HAVING c2 > (SELECT t2.x FROM t2 WHERE t2.y = SUM(t1.c3))

seg-source.mrk: SELECT c1 FROM t1 GROUP BY c1 HAVING c2 > (SELECT t2.x FROM t2 WHERE t2.y = SUM(t1.c3))

target.mrk: SELECT c1 FROM t1 GROUP BY c1 HAVING c2 > (SELECT t2.x FROM t2 WHERE t2.y = SUM(t1.c3))

trans-unit.source: A cursor declared on a ResultSet that includes an aggregate in the outer query block is not updatable.

seg-source.mrk: A cursor declared on a ResultSet that includes an aggregate in the outer query block is not updatable.

target.mrk: A cursor declared on a ResultSet that includes an aggregate in the outer query block is not updatable.
